dataSourceAttribution.displayName: TU114, MD, IOWA strain SNPs
dataSourceAttribution.description: Isolates MD and TU114, were maintained and crossed in adult immunosuppressed C57BL/6 mice (1 mg dexamethasone phosphate administered every second day (Yang et al., 2000)). Six days after the first injection, mice were infected orally with ~1000 oocysts. Oocysts were purified from mouse feces as previously described (Widmer et al., 1998). Briefly, samples were homogenized and the oocysts floated on a 15%/30% (w/v) Histodenz (N,N'-bis(2,3-dihydroxypropyl)acetamido-2,4,6-tri-iodo-isophthalamide) (Sigma, St. Louis, Miss.) step gradient. Oocysts were sometimes further purified with immunomagnetic separation using the Aureon Crypto Kit (Aureon Biosystems, Vienna, Austria). DNA was extracted from purified oocysts with the High Pure Template Preparation Kit (Roche Diagnostics, Indianapolis, Ind.) (Tanriverdi et al., 2002). DNA was eluted in 20-50 ul TE buffer, a concentration equivalent to 10^4 oocysts/ul. SNPs differentiating the isolates MD and TU114 were identified by sequencing randomly chosen fragments of 2-2.5 kb retrieved from the C. parvum genome sequence. Fragments were spaced at approximately 80 kb. PCR primers 20-30 bp long were designed with vector NTI software. PCR included approximately 10 ng DNA of parental isolates MD or TU114, 0.4 µM primers and PCR mix (Takara) to a final volume of 50µl. Amplifications were performed with the following temperature condition: denaturation at 94°C for 2 min was followed by 35 cycles of 94°C for 30 s, 50-55°C for 30 sec, 68°C for 1.5 2 min, and a final 5 min extension at 68°C. A portion of 5µl of each PCR product was run on 1% agarose. For PCR reactions giving a single band, 5µl PCR product was treated with 2 µl of ExoSAP-IT (USB) at 37°C for 30 min and 80°C for 15 min. If multiple PCR bands were present, the entire PCR reaction was run on a 1% agarose gel and the desired band extracted with a QIAquick gel extraction. PCR products were sequenced using two pairs of primers of opposite polarity located at 700-800 bp intervals. Primers were designed such that adjacent complementary sequences overlapped by 50-100 bp. Portions of approximately 50 ng PCR product (~50 ng) were used in 15 µl sequencing reactions (CEQ DTCS-Quick Start Kit). Sequencing reactions were run on a CEQ8000 Genetic Analysis System (Beckman Coulter). Sequences were analyzed the Contig Express program in Vector NTI. MD and TU114 sequences were aligned to find SNPs. Any SNP was confirmed in a minimum of two sequences. Some SNPs were also confirmed by independent PCR amplification of the genomic DNA .

contact.name: Jessica Kissinger
contact.institution: University of Georgia

dataSourceAttribution.description:
C. parvum oocysts (IOWA strain) were stored at 4°C. HCT8 cell infection was carried out according to previously reported conditions. Oocysts were counted using a hemocytometer and 2-2.5 x 107 oocysts were added to each culture dish at time (t) = 0 hr and incubated at 37°C and 5% CO2 After visual confirmation of excystation and attachment in culture (t= 2 hr), all samples were rinsed with warmed 1x Hanks buffered saline solution (HBSS). Infected cell cultures were lysed in TRIzol (Invitrogen) at 2, 6, 12, 24, 36, 48, and 72 hours post infection and stored at -80°C until RNA isolation. RNA was isolated from the samples and DNA contamination was degraded utilizing the Turbo DNA-free kit. cDNA synthesis was accomplished using Superscript III cDNA synthesis kit. Real Time PCR utilizing C. parvum 18S ribosomal RNA primers was completed to verify lack of DNA contamination as well as confirmation of successful cDNA synthesis for all 7 time points over 4 independent infection time courses (biological replicates).

For RT-PCR, Twenty microliter reactions were constructed using a 4 ul of template from a 1:100 dilution of synthesized cDNA (2 ug RNA starting concentration), 0.1 uM primer pairs and 2x AccuQuant SYBR Green SuperMix, with Low Rox (Quanta BioSciences, Inc.). RT-PCR was run on Stratagene Mx3000P or Mx3005P thermacyclers , with cycle conditions of: 1 cycle of initial denaturation (95°C for 1 minute), 45 PCR cycles (95°C for 1 minute, 58°C for 30 seconds and ramping to 60°C for 30s). Amplification was followed by melt curve generation via 1 minute at 95°C ramping down to 57°C in 2 degree intervals followed by ramping back up to 95°C for 30 seconds.

Primers for individual genes were tested on C. parvum genomic DNA for amplicon formation and efficiency. RT-PCR of the infection time course cDNA was performed in a 96 well format, with each of the 3281 gene primers (12 per plate) normalized to the corresponding time point's 18s rRNA amplification on each plate. Because of the high-throughput nature, each gene of interests' initial RNA concentration was estimated by fitting a 4 point logistic curve to the raw fluorescence amplification plot for each gene and 18s rRNA reactions. Post-normalization the median of the replicates (2-7 with an average of 4) was calculated for each time point. Standardization was performed relative to the maximum expression of a gene across time points
dataSourceAttribution.displayName: Expression profiling of C. parvum life cycle stages post-infection
